I would have ended up here without his support, but it may have taken a little longer, and it would have been harder. Today I'm over 400 days sober, paid off my credit cards (and then had a major car repair... so I'm starting over), and I quit smoking 8 months ago. I have a better job in a management position with more room for growth financially and professionally. I'm also 25lbs smaller because I quit drinking.
He always liked me for who I was. But now that I'm utilizing healthier coping skills (or at the very least, avoiding the really bad ones) I can be a better partner to him. His neverending support of me gives me an extra incentive to push through on days that are extra difficult. I know I have the skills to do these things on my own, but it's so validating to have someone around who has seen the changes firsthand and who has loved me through all of them.
Being vulnerable is so scary, but I'm so glad I found someone who got to know me in that state. I feel like he has a more solid understanding of who I am and how my experiences have shaped me than he would if we'd met 3 months later.
This is all just my experience, but I hope it offers you some perspective, even if you come to a different conclusion.

My personal experience,
I have oral HSV1 like most of the population. I get cold sores when I'm extremely stressed or really sick (usually once a year, but this year I've had 3 outbreaks) I avoid any oral contact with any of my partners from the first sign of an outbreak until a few days after it's gone away completely. Everyone else in our network is aware and totally okay with that.
As for genital HSV2, someone in our network has it and I'm totally okay with my partner playing with her because she's on antivirals and they would use protection 100%. Everyone isn't on board with that, though, so they don't engage in any play where exposure is a risk. No oral for her and no penetration. I think it's incredibly unfortunate as she's taking precautions and being proactive in communicating her status and reducing the risks. But I also understand the other side. HSV2 has so much more stigma and not everyone wants to open themselves to that risk at all.

WRITING.TITLE: Client's employee kissed me on the neck..
WRITING.TEXT:
For some context, I work for a woman who owns several different businesses. I run one of the retail stores day to day, but occasionally I run marketing events for one of the other businesses. Tonight I put on a marketing event and it was going really well. I was getting along with the building staff and the residents and they were responding really well to my pitches.
One of the building staff members asked me about one of my tattoos when I went to refill the food, and we talked about the video game reference for a minute. He was talking to me quite a lot, even following me back to my table and sitting behind it with me. He kept making the conversation really personal (example: he offered me wine, I said that I don't drink and he asked if I'm an alcoholic, which I am) and I kept interrupting him to talk to customers.
As the event was ending and I was packing up, he was socializing with his coworkers and residents. I was packing up my supplies and kept passing by the group. He asked me to hug him several times, and kept touching my back and my shoulders. He even said, "don't stop hugging me or I'll be really uncomfortable" which I responded to by pulling away and coming up with an excuse to walk away.
I tried to sneak away when I was leaving but he insisted on helping me to the car. I insisted that he not but he followed me anyway. Hew asked for my contact info and I told him I wasn't interested. He claimed that I misunderstood his intentions and he just thought I was cool and wanted to get to know me, he doesn't date people unless he knows them first. He kept insisting and I relented and said it was ok for him to give me his work number, since he claimed he was only interested in a professional relationship. After he gave me his number, I said goodbye (again) and he hugged me and kissed my neck before walking away.
My boss is livid. I've been a victim of sexual assault many times in my life, of many different kinds. I'm struggling here (as I always have) to figure out if what happened to me is "a big deal" or not.

You don't even need to delete WhatsApp. Just block her on it. And on every other social media account you use that you know she also uses. Focus on keeping the blocks in place and continuing to use your social media accounts the way you enjoy, without worrying about seeing her activity. It's easier to let the anxiety pass when you won't come across this person's content on accident and there's an active step (unblocking) between you and them. Whatever you do, don't unblock her. Time will help you heal. Spend time with friends or time alone taking care of yourself.
The anxiety that came from this person's erratic behaviors have likely been weighing on you for a while. At least it did in my anecdotal experience. I'm telling you, it won't work. He doesn't clean because he doesn't care and it doesn't bother him. It'll bother you to your core and you'll just resent him in a dirty house instead of a clean one.

I broke. But I should've left long before. I'd been cleaning up after him for a year and no amount of begging or pleading or chore charting ever helped.
My partner now isn't great at cleaning. He keeps his place presentable but has a hard time keeping up. Strongly consider if continuing to date someone who is content living in filth is something you're willing to put up with for the rest of your life.

I'm fully Poly but was open for an extended period. If she's the one pushing for this and it goes against the original framework that your relationship is based on, then starting out with rules doesn't go against the whole idea. The rules exist to provide you with structure and solid expectations during the transition from exclusive to open. Once you guys have been open for a while, and you find yourself more comfortable with the dynamic, then you can reassess later on and change the rules to match that.
She's allowed to have ideas about what she wants the dynamic to look like. But don't blindly agree to those if you're uncomfortable. You two need to find compromise and middle ground or things won't work out long term. She needs to be willing to take things extremely slow to accommodate you. She needs to be willing to provide you with extra care and affection, or whatever your love language is, to reaffirm her commitment to your relationship.

An open relationship should only be considered a next step in an otherwise stable, healthy relationship. Not a means to fix a broken one. Not that it couldn't work for you guys, but you need to get to a point where you are happy with your sex life before it can even be considered.

My experience with the court process is from when I was 10 years old. My mom's husband had been abusing me for 2 years. The first time they questioned me, I spoke to an officer alone. But my mom was present for the first physical exam they did, where they projected my genitals on a screen while they inspected me for tears. She was present for most of my testimonies moving forward, and I was rarely able to speak freely.
After 2 years, my mom convinced me to lie to the courts. Tell them I made it all up. It was easier for her to handle than following through with the rest of the process. She said he would live with his parents and financially support us, but I wouldn't ever have to see him again. In reality, he moved back in with us and I lived with him until I was 18.
I requested the court records a few years later. I blocked out so many memories from that time. He wrote a confession. He was facing life. I could've put him away. I was so close. For 6 more years he abused me, just in new ways. Here I am now, still dealing with where that left me.

This concept is a big part of the reason why I prefer to date poly people in my solo dating. Not that monogamous people or those in open relationships are incapable of that level of empathy. But I need the freedom to be able to build a connection knowing that it won't be affected negatively by another relationship out of my control. This isn't always realistic, but so long as there's an attempt to establish independent connections, I'm happy to work out the details individually.
In my experience from the couple side of things, we've tried really hard to accommodate potential partners. Matches often ask us what we're looking for, and that's so hard to answer. We're just looking for genuine people and taking things from there. We encourage the people we match with to figure out what their boundaries and comfort level in a group dynamic would be and we start from there. In some cases, they've asked to connect with one of us first and to meet the other after some time has passed. In some cases, we both go on independent dates with someone before we all get together. If we weren't attempting to provide what works for them, knowing we have the inherent privilege of an established relationship, we wouldn't be benefiting them at all. And benefiting everyone should be the whole damn point.

I totally agree! I make it a point, to some potential partners discomfort, to talk openly about my history of abuse and addiction on the first or second date. I'm sober with some experience with healthy relationships now, but the things I've been through provide important context for who I am and what I need from a partner. I could easily wait until later on to share those things, but they've been such a big part of my life that inform the way I think and the behaviors I'm willing to accept.
It makes the most sense to tell someone those things up front. I can tell a lot about someone by the way they respond to that conversation. Relationships are built on trust and honesty and I find that I'm comfortable giving that from the first moment. Even if I don't continue seeing that person, we always end up having genuine conversation and I'm grateful for the brief connection even if we aren't compatible

I relate to this so much from both sides. My partner and I are poly and almost completely date separately. We made a couple's profile on Tinder that he manages with the mindset that it would be really cool to meet someone that's into both of us, but we don't want to push someone that isn't into one of us. Our profile makes it clear that we aren't a package deal and sometimes people will ask to chat with one of us, which is totally okay. We've gone on quite a few group dates and had one go really well where all of us were into each other, and other scenarios where one of us continued to connect with that person. We're flexible because that's the only way to make sure you're not taking advantage of people or making them uncomfortable.
I have one couple that I still travel to see (when I can, rarely) that I hit it off with back when my ex and I were swinging. Part of why I like them so much is that our relationships were separate. They each went on dates with me independently and together, and we played independently and together. I never felt like I was forced to see both of them to keep things going, I could have chosen to only see one of them at any time. That's not something I've found with a local couple since I moved, though admittedly I haven't tried very hard because I have little patience for the kind of BS you've been dealing with.
Relationship dynamics are complicated. Adding a third person just exacerbates that. I've always gone into group scenarios (and all relationships, I suppose) with the idea that I want to figure out what dynamic works best for those involved, rather than finding a person to shove into an idea I've created.

You probably wouldn't qualify for any financial aid because your eligibility will be based on your parent's income until you're 24.
Coming from a 25 year old whose parents couldn't afford to provide what you have, stick with it and finish your degree. Save whatever extra money you can so that you have an emergency fund if something happens and you need some time to figure out how to support yourself. Make the most of office hours and extra curriculars relevant to your degree. Get as much as you can out of your college experience, because you have the time for those things that someone working full time can't manage.
Also consider that your parents don't have to know every detail of your life. I don't want to condone actively lying, but as long as you're being responsible and taking advantage of the opportunity they're providing you, you can easily withhold information from them if it's something you know they won't like.

The definition of agnostic is incorrect. The survey presents the definition as "belief in something, but don't know what" when the actual definition is "the belief that the existence of God or other spiritual beings is unverifiable and unknowable." Basically, the belief that we can neither confirm nor deny.
Agnosticism can apply to atheists and theists. Agnostic theism would be, "theres no verifiable proof that there's a God, but I think there is." Versus agnostic atheism, "there is no verifiable proof that there's a God, but I dont think there is."

I'm polyamorous and this is my take:
1. If you aren't comfortable with this, you should leave her, because insisting on this when you don't want it is incredibly disrespectful behavior on her end. 2. If this is something you want to try to be okay with, you both need to sit down and do research on setting rules and boundaries in nonmonogamous relationships. She won't have the right to go to someone's house unless you agree, and you shouldn't unless you are interested in an open relationship yourself. 3. She needs to take things at YOUR pace. Even if that means going on dates with no kissing, no touching, etc. So that you can work through your emotions regarding her seeing other people before you add in factors like sex and STIs.
I personally think she has someone in mind already, which is a HUGE no-no in newly opening relationships. Plus she seems unwilling to compromise on this even if it hurts you. Unfortunately, I can say I was much like her a few years ago and when I was dating someone who wanted to stay monogamous. You aren't compatible, and she isn't respecting you. You should move on. It will hurt a lot now, but you will suffer less in the long run because her seeing other people will hurt you just as much.
Edit to add: Opening up at a time when your relationship (and sex life) are rocky is a recipe for disaster. If she is unwilling to take weeks or months to make sure your relationship is rock solid before even considering this, then she is NOT cut out for a successful open relationship.

Typically, yes. But it's entirely possible for the soil in the center of the pot to be hard and dry from chronic underwatering (likely before you bought it, if you haven't had them long).
I give mine plenty of water when the top bit of soil gets dry, enough to make sure it runs out of the bottom of the pot. I only soak mine when they look like yours do. They pop right back up within a few hours.
I'm a florist, so I work with lots of peace lilies lol

Is it pot relatively light when you lift it? If so it's definitely underwatering. I don't think this would be overwatering unless it was sitting in standing water or overwatered consistently over a longer period of time.

It needs a good soaking. Let it sit under a running faucet for a while so the soil really soaks all the way through, and let it drain for a while before putting it back. It may need a bigger pot but the bigger issue is that it's definitely dehydrated.

Happened to me, too! I wasn't as good at telling creepy guys to fuck off back then, but I was still being pretty damn forward about my complete lack of interest. The complete lack of self awareness was astounding.
The OP does say they offered to try monogamy. But if the options are that OP changes himself or the relationship ends, which is what it seems like, then it really is a demand.

I would feel betrayed as well. Imagine the opposite scenario that people post about in non-monogamy subs all the time: When a partner in a monogamous relationships demands that they be able to see other people. That demand goes completely against the rules and boundaries that the relationship was built on and that their partner consented to.
It's entirely unfair of her to ask you to change. It's understandable that she struggles, non-monogamy isn't for everyone, nor is it easy for people who do seek it out. But the focus should be on finding a compromise that works for both of you, rather than there being an expectation that you completely change to accommodate her. Which is what it sounds like you're facing.
Maybe I'm extreme, but I wouldn't change such a large part of myself for someone, especially when they were aware of it for the duration of the relationship. I'd be willing to go to therapy, change our rules and boundaries in the interim, and do whatever I could to help them find peace of mind and reassurance.
Therapy is a must. Shes had a lot of time to process the feelings that come up when you foster other relationships. Therapy can help her understand them and figure out alternatives to dealing with them that also work for you. I wish you both the best of luck, and hope you can find a happy compromise.

It just wouldn't go away. I tried so many different things and it persisted. Some standard acne treatments made it worse, even. After discovering that fungal acne was a thing, I looked at pictures and some looked surprisingly similar to my acne. My worst areas were my jawline and the sides of my face. I figured, fuck it. Even if it isn't fungal acne, accounting for the possibility can't make things worse. I cut everything out of my routine that I had been using except Stridex (which is FA safe) and started a new routine from scratch. I started using FA safe products about 3 months ago, and it didn't get better right away, but I kept adding to my routine until I saw progress.
I was just in a wedding as a bridesmaid and I literally cried when I was shopping for color correctors and foundation a few weeks ago, but my skin has gotten so much better that the products actually worked to cover the blemishes that I still have.
You're right, I didnt consider that. I'll edit my post and be more mindful of that in the future!

My partner and I have been together for 9 months, and were both poly before getting together. We're both solo poly but at this point we're like primaries in a lot of ways.
Our rules are: Testing is mandatory before any exposure risks. After initial testing is done, oral and protected sex are okay. Dropping condoms is okay as long as it's been 3 months or more since they've had unprotected sex with another partner, unless that other partner has also been tested. We tell each other before things progress sexually with new partners to check in about their testing status.
Sometimes, due to weird circumstances, we don't follow these rules to the letter. Once he was with a long distance partner who had been tested but her results weren't due back for a few days. He asked me if I was comfortable with him taking the risk if it meant we stopped sexual contact until her results came back, and I was okay with that. But we always talk about the exact situation and weigh what the best compromise is.
Outside of that, we don't really have any other rules. It's just expected that we're open and honest with each other. I trust him completely :)
